newsitem.title: AUSTRIA: Austrian Airlines plans no 1996 dividend.
newsitem.headline: Austrian Airlines plans no 1996 dividend.

text.p: Austrian Airlines does not plan to pay a dividend for 1996 despite a rise in parent pre-tax earnings and a narrower operating loss, the state-controlled airline's directors Herbert Bammer and Mario Rehulka said.
"The shareholders' meeting will decide but we will not be proposing a dividend," Bammer told Reuters. "We want to carry our profit forward against losses from earlier years."
Austrian Airlines last paid a dividend of five schillings for 1991, the start of a four-year down-turn.

Parent operating loss narrowed to 77 million schillings last year from 120.8 million in 1995, Rehulka said. He reiterated that parent pre-tax profit rose to around 102 million schillings from 55.1 million.
A sharp rise in jet fuel prices last year brought 112 million schillings in additional costs, Bammer said. Personnel costs remained roughly constant at 3.087 billion schillings despite expansion.
The airline's seat load factor recovered to almost 59 percent in the second half of last year from 55 percent in the first half.
"We are looking for a significant improvement -- 62 percent this year alone," Bammer said.
Rehulka said the airline stood by its target of a 300 million schillings pre-tax profit in 1997.
Austrian Airlines announced last month it had taken a 36 percent stake in rival Lauda Air and acquired an option to buy an additional 30 percent.
The two firms have forecast an overall improvement in annual earnings of around 300 million schillings as a result of the deal. -- Janet McBride, Vienna newsroom, +43-1 531 12 254
